sentences.english: A barbershop in a lane The barber shop in the alley is convenient and cheap for neighbors so it is quite necessary.
sentences.chinese: 《胡同理发店》邻里间的便民服务，廉价而不可或缺。

sentences.english: Restraint is necessary counter-part to the winds of opposition.
sentences.chinese: 逆风而行时，束缚是不可或缺的。

sentences.english: The railway is not just inevitable, but vital to the future of Cranford.
sentences.chinese: 铁路不仅不可避免，对克兰福德的将来更是不可或缺。

sentences.english: "Performance Art" as independent voice can"t be absent this year.
sentences.chinese: 行为艺术“作为独立的声音今年仍然不可或缺。”

sentences.english: It with make the sound machine pedal similar, is good assistant of necessary performer.
sentences.chinese: 它与制音器踏板一样，是演奏者不可或缺的好助手。

sentences.english: Marking of Word Class in A New Century Chinese-English Dictionary;
sentences.chinese: 汉语四字成语是汉英词典中不可或缺的重要组成部分。

sentences.english: In some top-fermented beers, however, this flavor is essential.
sentences.chinese: 丁香类香味是上面发酵小麦啤酒不可或缺的特殊香味。

sentences.english: The oceanography outlook of the Pre-Qin Perios is an integral part of ancient Chinese marine culture.
sentences.chinese: 先秦海洋观念是中国古代海洋文化不可或缺的一环。

sentences.english: But it remains part and parcel of modern mother love.
sentences.chinese: 但是这些是现代母爱的不可或缺的一部分。

sentences.english: What part of the body is any--is essential?
sentences.chinese: 究竟哪个身体部位是不可或缺的？

sentences.english: Seals are an essential part of the spin pack operation.
sentences.chinese: 密封圈是网片不可或缺的一部分。
他把它们称为“不可或缺化”和“有形化”。

sentences.english: That Ronaldo is utterly essential to Real’s chances is unquestionable.
sentences.chinese: 毫无疑问，罗纳尔多对皇马是不可或缺的。

sentences.english: Chinese four-character idioms are a special yet important component of a Chinese-English dictionary.
sentences.chinese: 汉语四字成语是汉英词典中不可或缺的重要组成部分。

sentences.english: The vocalising of teaching material is a part could not absent in vocal teaching program.
sentences.chinese: 练声曲教材是声乐教学中不可或缺的一部分。

sentences.english: White meat, dark meat, you just can't lose.
sentences.chinese: 白肉，黑肉，对于你来说都是不可或缺的。

definition: see 必不可少[bi4 bu4 ke3 shao3]
lit. to speak of two things on the same day (idiom); to mention things on equal terms (often with negatives: you can't mention X at the same time as Y)
